displayed_text: Patient: And I have I mean it’s a fact. But that one time was bad so then I just had it um (pause) Doctor: Okay. Yeah Patient: Two weeks ago today and it wasn’t nearly as bad. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But it’s also not seeming to work like it did. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. I hear the PSA is starting to creep up a little. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ours isn’t back yet, but his is going up. Patient: Yeah I mean I… Doctor: Mhmm Patient: I think I started chemo and I was in the low thirties. I went down in to twenties and I’m back up to thirty I think the last one from B______. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. You know the lymph nodes are starting to grow again. Just plumpier um Patient: I had a CT scan

Patient: The Erlida? Doctor: The Erlida, yeah. Patient: Two weeks ago I think. Doctor: Two weeks. Okay. Patient: Well, let's see now. Family Member 1: When you came last week? No? Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them.

Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process? Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: There has been, uh, some trials where what they did is they took a patient who has spots in the bone and radiated one spot and give it immunotherapy. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And in, in having an immune drug on board seems to make that whole thing work better. Um, I don’t have the answer for this vaccine radium combination, whether it’s going to do anything. But that’s, that’s the idea behind it is let’s bring these two things together. Uh, so, uh, again, if I had to say which one has the best chance of working for you right now is probably going to be a second hormone treatment. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and I think given where you are with the disease in the bone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I, I would probably lean towards something that I’d feel like we have a better chance of, of success. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Probably a program. Doctor: ‘Cuz we would put the prescription into our pharmacy. We would have them figure out how much it’s gonna cost you, and then if it’s too much, they could start looking for these plans that they cover the cost for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if that’s so, then it would be cheap. Then you would be taking a drug that I don’t think is gonna work with the idea that I need you to be on this drug so that the immune therapy might work which is research, experimental, unsure. Okay? Family Member: Is there any way on the portal – his daughter wants to keep up what’s, what’s going over -- like what we said today. Does she have your power of something? Have some way that she can check on, uh – like MyLGHHealth, I can go in there and see, read everything, and results and that. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, he is active on MyChart. That’s where I wrote you that note. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So he can let her – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: He can give her the password. The system doesn’t know who’s looking. You know, but it is his password. Family Member: Right. Okay. Doctor: Okay? But you need to be able to call her or talk to her or you have to sign forms out front to give me release. Okay?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. And, so, now they’re escalating the dose of this natural product. Um. Family Member: Is that, uh, a stem cell or cell therapy or is it a -- Doctor: No, it comes like from a, I--I’d have to look. Whether it comes from a seed cucumber or-- Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or a pine co—Oh, it’s—I’d have to look it up. But, it’s, it’s a natural thing that, that, they have --- Patient: It’s organic medicine.

Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Why do you make me work so hard? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: My brain is on overdrive. Nice to see you both. I’m like racking my brain to see how to move forward and I’m just bummed out that you’re still in pain. Is this right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Same place? Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: When asked if my ethnic group receives the same care as other ethnic groups, I said no, because as a white person I'm aware that people of other ethnicities often don't get as good of treatment or aren't taken as seriously as I am, rather than that I'm treated less well because of my race. I want to be clear about this as the question doesn't specify.

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: For this, I’ve got a, I think for this, the trial, they were able to use the experience with Germany to say you probably could start about here. You don’t have to start way down here. And I don’t think it’s the same exactly like a regular drug phase one. So I think they’re kind of already in a in a sort of Goldilocks spot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So that’s the only difference between you know in Germany everybody gets, they individualize it based on what they looked at is how much of the scan is your cancer taking off. They try, they, they describe what they said that if you took up that much material, you need to get this much. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So they give, they dose it based on how much of an exposure. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, I think, again, what’s the best way to go? I mean the groups in Germany have way more experience doing this. Family Member: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh but you know it’s more complicated because you’ve got to go to Germany and all that, all those, there’s, there’s a layer to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Although you know saying that, you still would have to go away from home.

Family Member: Maybe put that down so you can focus some again on the radium study. Doctor: So I, I was going to talk to you about a radioactive thing we have that’s very specifically targeted the prostate cancer cells. Uh, I keep telling folks about it, and then it keeps taking too long, and we haven’t opened the trial yet. I thought we were going to open it in August. It’s now December. Family Member: What’s the name of it? Patient: Radium. Doctor: Well, no, the radium’s a different thing. So the radium, uh, this is called, this is just, it’s P-S-M-A, targeted, uh. Family Member: But it hasn’t gotten here yet? They looking at it in kind of-? Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval. Doctor: They don’t need, uh, even data showing that it proves survival. It’s sort of, if, if the doctor feels it could be beneficial, they’re allowed to use it. So they’re not allowed to sell it. They not allowed to make money. So what they’ve been doing is based on using the same material to image prostate cancer. So we give this material with a little bit of radiation on it and it looks really good. We could see spots that we maybe didn’t see before. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The idea was, well, if we can swap out the little bit of radiation and put a lot of radiation, maybe we could treat cancer. So they’ve been treating people kind of on an individual basis. Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. So they’ve been reporting look how good Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So in the U.S., we kind of have to go down more organized, you know, step-wise fashion. Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Get it done. Come on C__, come on over here. Doctor: She’s out of here. Patient: You know what man. Doctor: Here’s your starter kit. Patient: What is this?. Doctor: There’s some information for you about what this medicine is. And this medicine so see… no wait (pages turning) Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: There’s only one, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue, okay. Doctor: Then less common there’s a whole bunch of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: Back pain, diarrhea, flashes, edema. So it’s everything that you had last…

Family Member: Every time you go there I mean you can’t get in to see him. I mean you’re there for hours. Doctor: I B___ City? Patient: B___ City, yeah. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So… Patient: So yeah I’d rather see somebody… Family Member: We burned that bridge. Patient: I’d rather see somebody… yeah can’t go back to that. Doctor: I know because honestly then maybe and that probably should get fixed – Family Member: Yes. Doctor: - even if we make decisions about chemotherapy or something we cannot afford to have a major source of infection sitting right there. So definitely that will hold up a lot of our decisions about other treatments for sure.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: So you’re not into it, but it, it just tastes really good. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then there’s the H___ C___, which is also pretty good. Family Member: I’ve heard of it. Okay. Doctor: Right across the street. Family Member: Oh. Patient: You know me better than that. Family Member: Seeing the head doctor. Patient: I’m kind of hanging outside of these. Doctor: Nice. It was good to see you. I’ve got to put up with this all by myself. Family Member: I know. I mean I got a little sick this year, too, so. Didn’t we tell you?

Patient: You know, I feel good. Doctor: That’s good. Let’s see and you’re sixty… Patient: No I’m fifty-nine. Doctor: Fifty-nine. Patient: I’m not sixty yet. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It’s alright. (laughs) Doctor: Fifty-nine. And generally men under sixty have a recurrence I mean are able to have a sexual function even without medication ultimately. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So I suspect that you’ll probably be there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? It’s still early.

Family Member: And then you eat breakfast. Patient: And then I’ll get up again and check it again. Doctor: Alright. Yeah. I think you could get off the carbs. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It would be better. That’s all. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Just quit getting – we can’t have spaghetti for Father’s Day. Doctor: No. You can have squash spaghetti. Family Member: Yeah. I could see my daughter-in-law making that. (Laughter) Doctor: I’m just saying, you can have spaghetti, just not pasta. Family Member: Pasta. Right. Not cereal. We need to get rid of the Special K. Doctor: No cereal. No bread. No pasta.

Patient: Yeah, the drops have been wonderful. Doctor: --because the nerves affecting things is a big problem. If that happens, then that's tougher to reverse. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So let's go one notch slightly lower in terms of your dose. Patient: Okay. Yeah, I missed it yesterday, I was going to come in all dressed up as a doctor, and-- Doctor: Yep. Healthcare Professional: So we just need to do a date clarification 'cause- so the pharmacy can use the last order the last time. Just have to change today’s date, so. Doctor: You could probably talk the medical lingo pretty easily now. Patient: Yeah, right. (Slight laughter) Healthcare Professional: Yes. Patient: I saw a news lady on TV --- Doctor: Uh, huh. Patient: -- And I thought of, I thought of T____.

Family Member: Tired. Doctor: I know it’s been long. Thanks for your patience. Um sit over here. Patient: Sure. Family Member: Sure. Doctor: I know I’m going to take you away from your wife but I’d rather we look at each other than my back. Patient: Yeah, sure. Doctor: Blood pressure’s a little high today. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Is that wrong for you or you just came in rushing? Patient: No, no, it’s usually pretty good, about one forty, one fifty at the highest. So that is a little high, yeah. Doctor: Are you taking Ondansetron? That’s for nausea. Patient: Uh occasionally, not as much as I did when I was going through radiation. Doctor: So occasionally, like once a week, once a month?
